content.raw:
Okay, yeah, after looking at the `ignition-cmake0-config-version.cmake`, that's correct.

For some reason I thought we were only comparing the major version number, but it's actually using cmake's native `VERSION_LESS`, so this should work just fine.
content.html:
Okay, yeah, after looking at the ignition-cmake0-config-version.cmake, that's correct.

For some reason I thought we were only comparing the major version number, but it's actually using cmake's native VERSION_LESS, so this should work just fine.

content.raw: but it wouldn't accept 0.3 right? it would have to be greater than 0.4 to be accepted?
content.html: but it wouldn't accept 0.3 right? it would have to be greater than 0.4 to be accepted?

content.raw: I'll create an issue for this in `ign-cmake`.
content.html: I'll create an issue for this in ign-cmake.

content.raw:
It might be worth noting that our versioning will consider `0.4.0` to be "compatible" with any `0.x.x`.

Since find-module tweaks are likely to be a consistent thing for `ign-cmake` we might want to consider customizing the versioning semantics so that any requested version `x.y` will be considered "compatible" with any installed version `u.v` where `u==x` and `v>=y`.
content.html:
It might be worth noting that our versioning will consider 0.4.0 to be "compatible" with any 0.x.x.

Since find-module tweaks are likely to be a consistent thing for ign-cmake we might want to consider customizing the versioning semantics so that any requested version x.y will be considered "compatible" with any installed version u.v where u==x and v>=y.

content.raw:
As of 816ccbb this branch should now be fully supported on Windows, compiled against Visual Studio 2017.

After resolving the timeout issues, there was one last issue related to DLLs and ZeroMQ. Basically, if `ign-transport` is compiled as a DLL, then `NodeShared` will be destructed during the DLL teardown phase. It turns out that DLL teardown in Windows is a little chaotic, and we get some failed assertions from ZeroMQ while `NodeShared` is destructed. An easy solution is to just never destruct `NodeShared` on Windows. In the future we should consider investigating a cleaner solution, but this should get us by for now.

I also needed to stretch out some of the wait times because it seems that Windows isn't as fast at multithreading as Linux.

Finally, I needed to make this f111b9c tweak so that `BUILD_TESTING=OFF` would work properly.

At long last, I can give this pull request my approval. :joy:
content.html:
As of 816ccbb this branch should now be fully supported on Windows, compiled against Visual Studio 2017.

After resolving the timeout issues, there was one last issue related to DLLs and ZeroMQ. Basically, if ign-transport is compiled as a DLL, then NodeShared will be destructed during the DLL teardown phase. It turns out that DLL teardown in Windows is a little chaotic, and we get some failed assertions from ZeroMQ while NodeShared is destructed. An easy solution is to just never destruct NodeShared on Windows. In the future we should consider investigating a cleaner solution, but this should get us by for now.

I also needed to stretch out some of the wait times because it seems that Windows isn't as fast at multithreading as Linux.

Finally, I needed to make this f111b9c tweak so that BUILD_TESTING=OFF would work properly.

At long last, I can give this pull request my approval.

content.raw:
For what it's worth, I wound up implementing both versions last night.

- Here's what the changes look like for [only supporting 2017](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-transport/commits/d0f72462652540b5975f0eca78dcc9d62488ead4?at=ign-transport4).
- Here's what the changes look like for [supporting both 2013 and 2017](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-transport/branches/compare/5e95622%0D5ddccd7#diff)

The branch is currently set to the latter, but I can revert it to only supporting 2017 if that's what we would prefer. It would certainly allow our code to be simpler.
content.html:
For what it's worth, I wound up implementing both versions last night.

  • Here's what the changes look like for only supporting 2017.
  • Here's what the changes look like for supporting both 2013 and 2017

The branch is currently set to the latter, but I can revert it to only supporting 2017 if that's what we would prefer. It would certainly allow our code to be simpler.

content.raw:
We are only promising support for Mac and Linux (mostly via Ubuntu) when we release gazebo9. We can make ign-transport4 work with MSVC 2017, and leave gazebo9 on MSVC 2013 with the full understanding that it's broken and that CI will be (might be? I don't pretend to understand Windows) broken.

After the initial release of gazebo9 we can patch gazebo9 to use MSVC 2017, if possible. Otherwise, we will make the necessary changes on gazebo default.

So, I'm in agreement with Steve that we should target MSVC 2017 for both ign-transport and gazebo9, with the added note that we don't have to make changes to gazebo9 this month.
content.html:
We are only promising support for Mac and Linux (mostly via Ubuntu) when we release gazebo9. We can make ign-transport4 work with MSVC 2017, and leave gazebo9 on MSVC 2013 with the full understanding that it's broken and that CI will be (might be? I don't pretend to understand Windows) broken.

After the initial release of gazebo9 we can patch gazebo9 to use MSVC 2017, if possible. Otherwise, we will make the necessary changes on gazebo default.

So, I'm in agreement with Steve that we should target MSVC 2017 for both ign-transport and gazebo9, with the added note that we don't have to make changes to gazebo9 this month.

content.raw: I realize that we are already in feature freeze for gazebo9 and this might require some changes, but I think those would count as bug fixes
content.html: I realize that we are already in feature freeze for gazebo9 and this might require some changes, but I think those would count as bug fixes

content.raw: I lean toward dropping support for VS 2013 to simplify the code and aiming to support VS 2017 in gazebo9.
content.html: I lean toward dropping support for VS 2013 to simplify the code and aiming to support VS 2017 in gazebo9.

update.title: Use ign-cmake

content.raw:
Update on Windows support: I've figured out the source of the timeout issue. MSVC 2013 apparently had some bug related to `std::thread`, and a workaround was put in to mitigate the issue. Now when compiled with MSVC 2017, that workaround is causing programs that use `ign::transport::Discovery` to never quit, even after all their tests have finished running. This causes the test program to timeout, even thought it finished running all its tests.

I can fix this pretty easily using compile-time directives to check what version of MSVC is being run, and then choosing to use or not use the workaround based on where we're being compiled. The catch is, I'm not sure whether this is an issue in MSVC 2015, so I'm not sure about which exact number to check for. I'm hesitant to install MSVC 2015 and rebuild everything against it to find out, because that will be very time consuming and the code freeze is somewhat imminent.

For now, should I just assume that 2015 requires the workaround? If we later discover that 2015 should actually *not* have the workaround, we would just need to change a number in a small handful of places.

An alternative would be to remove the workaround entirely, but then we'd have to migrate the Windows CI of `gazebo9` (which I believe depends on `ign-transport4`) to use Visual Studio 2017.
content.html:
Update on Windows support: I've figured out the source of the timeout issue. MSVC 2013 apparently had some bug related to std::thread, and a workaround was put in to mitigate the issue. Now when compiled with MSVC 2017, that workaround is causing programs that use ign::transport::Discovery to never quit, even after all their tests have finished running. This causes the test program to timeout, even thought it finished running all its tests.

I can fix this pretty easily using compile-time directives to check what version of MSVC is being run, and then choosing to use or not use the workaround based on where we're being compiled. The catch is, I'm not sure whether this is an issue in MSVC 2015, so I'm not sure about which exact number to check for. I'm hesitant to install MSVC 2015 and rebuild everything against it to find out, because that will be very time consuming and the code freeze is somewhat imminent.

For now, should I just assume that 2015 requires the workaround? If we later discover that 2015 should actually not have the workaround, we would just need to change a number in a small handful of places.

An alternative would be to remove the workaround entirely, but then we'd have to migrate the Windows CI of gazebo9 (which I believe depends on ign-transport4) to use Visual Studio 2017.

update.title: Use ign-cmake

content.raw:
It seems there's an overview of the ZeroMQ API [here](http://api.zeromq.org/master:_start). I don't know for sure if that's a comprehensive list, but (edit) we can check for what functions didn't exist in version 4.0.

Here's a summary of what was added in 4.1 that didn't exist in 4.0:

- zmq_gssapi - secure authentication and confidentiality
- zmq_has - check a ZMQ capability
- zmq_msg_gets - get message metadata property
- zmq_tipc - 0MQ unicast transport using TIPC

I couldn't find any of those being used in `ign-transport`. CPPZMQ does make use of `zmq_msg_gets`, but it shouldn't affect us for two reasons:

1. It's only used in the function `zmq::message_t::gets(~)`, and we don't use that function.
2. The declaration/definition of that function is protected by an `#if` directive that checks the version number of libzmq, so we don't have to worry about it attempting to compile if we're using `4.0`.

I think we can pretty safely conclude that version `4.0` will be safe to build against.
content.html:
It seems there's an overview of the ZeroMQ API here. I don't know for sure if that's a comprehensive list, but (edit) we can check for what functions didn't exist in version 4.0.

Here's a summary of what was added in 4.1 that didn't exist in 4.0:

  • zmq_gssapi - secure authentication and confidentiality
  • zmq_has - check a ZMQ capability
  • zmq_msg_gets - get message metadata property
  • zmq_tipc - 0MQ unicast transport using TIPC

I couldn't find any of those being used in ign-transport. CPPZMQ does make use of zmq_msg_gets, but it shouldn't affect us for two reasons:

  1. It's only used in the function zmq::message_t::gets(~), and we don't use that function.
  2. The declaration/definition of that function is protected by an #if directive that checks the version number of libzmq, so we don't have to worry about it attempting to compile if we're using 4.0.

I think we can pretty safely conclude that version 4.0 will be safe to build against.

content.html: I think that it should work but hard to know without actually trying.

content.raw:
Do we need to be this specific about the version? What if we do `ign_find_package(ZeroMQ VERSION 4 REQUIRED PRIVATE)` instead? That should allow Xenial to get `4.1.0` while Windows is able to get the latest version (`4.2.3`).

I think the question boils down to whether `4.0.x` would be an acceptable version. @caguero would you happen to know if there's anything wrong with allowing `4.0` versions?
content.html:
Do we need to be this specific about the version? What if we do ign_find_package(ZeroMQ VERSION 4 REQUIRED PRIVATE) instead? That should allow Xenial to get 4.1.0 while Windows is able to get the latest version (4.2.3).

I think the question boils down to whether 4.0.x would be an acceptable version. @caguero would you happen to know if there's anything wrong with allowing 4.0 versions?

content.raw: sounds good
content.html: sounds good

content.raw:
Ah, right, because of the `${ZeroMQ_TARGET}` variable. Basically, we need to link to the ZeroMQ target, but on Windows that target is called `libzmq` because that's the name that the ZeroMQ developers chose for it, and we're importing their target. CMake 3.5.1 doesn't have the ability to alias an imported target, so we need to use a variable to hold the target name to make sure that we'll link to the target regardless of the platform.

We could do a temporary workaround where `ign-transport` chooses which target it links to based on the platform it's running on, but I'd rather not freeze the code in that state. I feel like this PR and the `ign-cmake` PR should be sort of viewed as a package deal since their purposes are so tightly coupled.
content.html:
Ah, right, because of the ${ZeroMQ_TARGET} variable. Basically, we need to link to the ZeroMQ target, but on Windows that target is called libzmq because that's the name that the ZeroMQ developers chose for it, and we're importing their target. CMake 3.5.1 doesn't have the ability to alias an imported target, so we need to use a variable to hold the target name to make sure that we'll link to the target regardless of the platform.

We could do a temporary workaround where ign-transport chooses which target it links to based on the platform it's running on, but I'd rather not freeze the code in that state. I feel like this PR and the ign-cmake PR should be sort of viewed as a package deal since their purposes are so tightly coupled.
